Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Groundwater teleconnections with interannual to multidecadal climate variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
The potential effects of climate variability and change on water resources is a well recognized and urgent concern from the local to global scale ? one that has increasingly become a high priority for groundwater managers and policy makers. The strategic importance of groundwater to global water and food security will likely intensify under climate change as more frequent and intense climate extremes increase variability in precipitation, soil moisture, and surface-water availability. However, the reliable characterization and forecast of responses in groundwater to climate change is complicated by the complex, heterogeneous nature of global-scale atmospheric-ocean circulation systems that partially control interannual to multidecadal climate variability and associated periodic and reversible patterns in terrestrial hydrology. Natural climate variability on these time scales influences precipitation distribution in space and time, drought frequency and severity, snowmelt runoff, streamflow, and other hydrologic processes that can profoundly affect surface-water resources. Some studies have inferred teleconnections between global-scale atmospheric-ocean forcings and groundwater. Yet, few have established strong evidence of causal relation between interannual to multidecadal climate variability and recharge rates and mechanisms ? many important process-level questions remain.

This project will fill this critical knowledge gap by testing the hypothesis that transient recharge rates and corresponding groundwater-level fluctuations respond to the complex, heterogeneous interactions of local-scale vadose zone processes and properties and global-scale atmospheric-ocean circulation systems. In particular, our research will quantifying the frequency, intensity, and phase relation of nonstationary signals in long-term climatic and hydrologic time series data from 15 of the most important U.S. Principal Aquifers, and correlate the teleconnections to the 6 leading atmospheric-ocean circulation systems that affect U.S. climate variability. We will evaluate constructive and destructive interference of teleconnection signals in precipitation, and the filtering in the vadose zone that dampens those signals, eventually producing an altered recharge time series. We will use this insight to evaluate the relative importance of the atmospheric-ocean circulation systems on transient recharge rates under future climate change scenarios. The expected results will have a broad impact because time-varying rates of recharge will improve local to national-scale groundwater models and sustainability studies. The project creates rich and engaging teaching, training, and learning experience for undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups in STEM. Additionally, we establish a model collaboration that enhances research and education between students and faculty from non-Ph.D. and Ph.D. granting institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: RUI: Groundwater teleconnections with interannual to multidecadal climate variability

Federal Award ID: 1316553

The project outcomes provide insight into the potential effects of climate variability and change on groundwater resources, which is a well-recognized and urgent concern from the local to global scale – one that has increasingly become a high priority for groundwater-resource managers and policy makers in the United States (U.S.). Groundwater is the largest distributed store of freshwater and plays a critical role in sustaining ecosystems, supporting agriculture, and enabling human adaptation to climate variability and change. The strategic importance of groundwater to global water and food security will likely intensify under climate change as more frequent and intense climate extremes (droughts and floods) increase variability in precipitation, soil moisture, and surface-water availability. However, the reliable characterization and forecast of responses in water resources to climate change by human activities is complicated by the complex, heterogeneous nature of global-scale atmospheric-ocean circulation systems that partially control interannual to multidecadal climate variability and associated periodic and reversible patterns in terrestrial hydrology. Scientists, managers, and policy makers have a limited understanding of the teleconnections between the global-scale forcings of natural climate variability and the sustainability of groundwater resources. This is of particular concern for the sustainability of U.S. Principal Aquifers (PAs), which are regional aquifer systems of national significance because of their high productivity and are critically important sources of potable water.

 This project answers the question Do groundwater levels and recharge in PAs respond to global-scale atmospheric-ocean circulation systems? We have systematically tested the hypothesis that transient recharge rates and corresponding groundwater-level fluctuations in most PAs are significantly controlled by complex interactions of interannual to multidecadal climate variability. The frequency, intensity, and phase relation of nonstationary signals in long-term climatic and hydrologic time series data from the ten most heavily used PAs were quantified and correlated to the six leading atmospheric-ocean circulation systems that affect U.S. climate variability. The six systems include the Atlantic teleconnection patterns: Arctic Oscillation (AO), North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), and Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO); and Pacific teleconnection patterns: El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO), Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), and Pacific-North American Oscillation (PNA). We used numerical unsaturated-flow models to estimate transient recharge rates in response to AO, NAO, AMO, ENSO, PDO, and PNA variability. Results from the numerical models help support the hypotheses that sediment texture and thickness of the vadose zone dampens time-varying teleconnection signals between AO, NAO, AMO, ENSO, PDO, and PNA and transient recharge rates. Project findings provide important insight into the appropriate conditions and limitations of using the assumption of steady-state recharge fluxes for aquifers across the U.S., and how oscillations associated with global-scale climate variability result in transient recharge at local scales. The project outcomes are a framework that generally explains why some periodic infiltration fluxes associated with climate variability are unexpectedly absent in groundwater level fluctuations and dampen with depth in the vadose zone, resulting in steady-state recharge fluxes, while other periodic surface fluxes do not dampen with depth, resulting in transient recharge. The project shows that given the general range of conditions representative of the continental U.S., transient recharge fluxes in response to the climate variability patterns of AO, NAO, ENSO, and possibly PDO could be detected at the depth of the water table in most aquifers.   

 The outcomes of this study have important broader impacts because time-varying rates of recharge will greatly improve local to national-scale groundwater models and sustainability studies, which will benefit many urban, agricultural, and environmental stakeholders. The project created a rich network for discovery and learning by partnering Masters and undergraduate students at San Francisco State University with Faculty at University of Arizona, Santa Clara University, and Research Hydrologists at the U.S. Geological Survey. The project leveraged and enhanced research and learning for undergraduates in the NSF supported Climate Change Scholars program at SFSU, which is a primarily undergraduate institution whose student body is highly diverse in underrepresented groups in STEM. International networks and partnerships were also strengthened between U.S. students and scientists through collaboration with the UNESCO GRAPHIC (Groundwater and Climate Change) project. Findings were broadly disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and by student- and faculty-led presentations at national and international scientific conferences. The project also broadly enhanced technological understanding through training workshops for early-career scientists and students on methods used in hydroclimatology. The hydroclimatology curriculum has been integrated into two undergraduate and graduate courses at San Francisco State University.
